title: Highgate Common Walking Route

images.title: Barrie Eyre / The Pool, Highgate Common
images.caption: The Pool, Highgate Common. Small pool with water lilies

images.title: Roger  Kidd / Camp Farm, near Highgate Common, Staffordshire
images.caption: Camp Farm, near Highgate Common, Staffordshire The woodland behind the farm is at the edge of Highgate Country Park, which is readily accessible by the public.

images.title: Roger  Kidd / The Road to Highgate Common
images.caption: The Road to Highgate Common. Just "creeping" onto the square, the road bends round towards Camp Farm, through pastureland and patches of mixed woodland, dominated by birch trees.

images.title: Roger  Kidd / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)
images.caption: Bridleway near Highgate Common. This bridleway starts at SO830936 where the roughly surfaced Forest Lane meets the lane to Halfpenny Green. After 600m. it narrows to a track through the edge of mixed deciduous woodland dominated by oak and birch.

images.title: Woodland on Highgate Common, Staffordshire by Roger  Kidd, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Woodland and autumn colours. The ground is particularly hospitable to rabbits, which have excavated large warrens.

images.title: Footpath and bench on Highgate Common, Staffordshire by Roger  Kidd, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Footpath and bench

images.title: Highgate Car Park View by Gordon Griffiths, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A view of the good sized Car Park

images.title: Track with birch trees near Highgate Common, Staffordshire by Roger  Kidd, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Track with birch trees

description: This walk follows the numerous trails on Highate Common - a designated country park and local nature reserve near Wolverhampton.  Here you will find 320 acres of lowland heath covered with heather, broom and gorse. There are also areas of woodland, with silver birch, pendunculate oak and coniferous plantation. Also look out for a variety of wildlife including lizards, Slow Worms, Grass Snakes, Rabbits, Bush-crickets, moths, beetles, flies, and Dragonflies. If you would like to continue your walk then the Staffordshire Way is a good option as it runs right through the park. The park is located a few miles south west of the city of Wolverhampton.
